entries.meaning: (now UK dialectal) Soft; tender; sensitive; yielding.
(now UK dialectal) Delicate; weak; poor-spirited; susceptible to cold weather, harsh conditions etc.

description: From Middle English neschen, from Old English hnesƒãan, hnesƒãian (‚Äúto make soft, soften; become soft, give way, waver‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *hnaskw≈çn (‚Äúto make soft‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *knƒìs-, *kenes- (‚Äúto scratch, scrape, rub‚Äù). Cognate with Old High German nasc≈çn ("to nibble at, parasitise, squander"; > German naschen (‚Äúto nibble, pinch‚Äù)). Doublet of nosh.

verbs.description: nesh (third-person singular simple present neshes, present participle neshing, simple past and past participle neshed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make soft, tender, or weak.
(intransitive, dialectal, Northern England) To act timidly.
